I found myself picking one spell to use for a fight and sticking with it.  I know this will not be the case for everyone but was for me and therefore I brought it up.  All in all a very enjoyable game and I would recommend this game to anyone.

Posted: November 13, 2015
												For those of us who remember spending rainy Sunday afternoons playing games like Dungeon Hack or Shadow Caster this is a welcomed re-awakening of a genre.  The graphics are superb, the controls are tight and the interface is simple enough while maintaining the desired level of PC complexity that many of us wish was still prevalent today in gaming.The combat is fun although tactical a tad simplistic.  I have found that the most effective strategy is to lure enemies one at a time into a 2 x 2 or larger area and simply strafe around while your attack recharge.  The game does do an effective job of complicating this simple strategic by throwing multiple enemies at you at once which leads to some wonderfully frantic fights but these are (thankfully) not too common.The puzzles are challenging while remaining logical and almost every puzzle hint that I found proved both valuable in discovering the solution without being to obvious while also adding to both the story and the atmosphere.  Also the reward of finding many of the game's secrets is very fulfilling!All in all well worth the price of admission for those looking for a modern take on a classic genre.  I am hopeful that the sequel carries on with this level of fun and frustration as the dungeon crawler rises again!

												Fantastic game to play, with well thought out content.However, I wish some aspects would be rethought/removed. For instance, the Spiders, completely OP with the poisoning. Rapid attack with a high chance of poisoning, even when equipped with poison resistance. That's all well and good, if you have a never ending supply of Anti-venom potions. These are easy enough to make, using only one herb and a refundable bottle. From the moment I started up until the first spider encounter I saved the herb to make the Anti-venom, which lasted me a good 8/9 poisonings. Considering the front two party members can both be poisoned, on the same attack, you burn through the potions incredibly fast. That wouldn't be a problem had they made the herb a common find. You just end up having to run back to the Crystal every time you are poisoned, or waiting it out, sleeping, until it wears off. What is the point in the potion, if it only lasts you 5/6 spider encounters, and then your running back and fourth just to remove poisoning? Pointless, in my opinion, it just makes the game incredibly boring.What should be done with the potion is that it gives you poison immunity for a set amount of time. That way you wouldn't burn through every potion to the point you are using the Crystal to remove poison.It's just a bad aspect of the game, in my opinion.Other than that it is fantastic. Great little puzzles, although stupidly easy. I recommend this to any RPG lover. I would say it is aimed more towards old D&D players, or people that don't mind movement and fighting restrictions.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Pretty good game overall. Probably about 18 hours straight out from beginning to end and it never really became monotonous. I haven't played a dungeon crawler like this in over a decade so I don't really have a good rule of measure as to how good the good parts are.The upsides are: the puzzle system, basic loot system that isn't way over the top like most white washed rpgs(getting a sword is a big deal), finding secrets and the multiflloor nature of the dungeons(falling down holes to find secrets), the logistics system(food, rest, potions)The downsides are: a poor magic system(clicking runes instead of casting spells with one click makes having more than one mage a pain), the lack of integration between party members in combat e.g. Ogre Battle 64 has a combat system with more depth and it uses pretty much the same frontline tank back line nuke system; no comboing off your mages.The battle system is pretty basic: click and swipe and kite around in a sqaure; use your mage nuke to pull.I played with an insectoid warrior and minotaur warrior in front row and a human rogue and insectoid mage(poison) in back row. Rogue had 12 points in assassination so it could attack from back row with daggers.If the mages casting system was better I would do another play through but as is I don't feel like manually clicking runes over and over in the middle of battle.If you play fps a fair amount it is a good idea to remap the strafe and turn keys.

												Legend of Grimrock is a classic dungeon-diving game. You play as four criminals who have been chained together and tossed into the seemingly endless labyrinth of Grimrock. Loads of enemies, puzzles, secrets and loot await you. The game also has an interesting combat style. You move around on tiles like moving on a game board, and each of your four party members can attack individually, though they always move with each other and face the same direction. Positioning is really important, and things can get frantic when you have more than a couple of enemies in a tiny room with you. Lots of fun, definitely recommend it, especially if you like games that make you think, with lots of hidden stuff to find.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												Legend of Grimrock is a first person RPG dungeon crawler reminescent of old school RPG of the same genre. It takes what was good of those old games while taking almost nothing of the bad, clunky stuff in the process.The story is kept really short: 4 criminals (your party) are brought by soldiers at the top of Mount Grimrock and sent to die in its dungeon. They fall into a huge pit that leads to the first level of the maze itself, and they can't go back. And that's basically it for the story. I mean sure, there is some kind of plot - for example there's a guy that talks in your sleep that is trying to help you get out, and there are some documents around the dungeon that fill in some details about the place - but you don't really care about it and the game doesn't really make you care for it. It's absolutely not the main focus of the game and it's perfectly fine in my opinion. This is a game that is mostly played for the gameplay aspect and the adventure.At the start of the game you can create your party of characters (with a good amount of options for stats and abilities, and even different races) or take premade ones, but whichever you choose everyone starts the same. No equipment, not even some clothing: you have to find things as you go through the maze. There's also some kind of survival mechanic, as you need to keep your characters fed with the food that you find in the dungeon, but it's not that big of a deal really.The combat is pretty straightforward: you just click the weapons that your character has in possession in one of his hands, then you have to wait a while to recharge its attack. But you also need to be aware of how to move in this game: you can't just stand still while you fight. You have to circle around the enemy, try to not get stuck in a corner and so on. Fights can be pretty tense, and they only get more tense as you go on through the game.Exploration is probably my favourite part though. Each level (that is each floor that you're exploring) in the game has increasingly difficult puzzles, and they are kept smart enough and interesting throughout the adventure. It's especially fun and exciting to find secrets when you carefully explore the environment and find out that you can open a passage in a wall by pressing this hidden button and find awesome equipment for your characters. By the way, a lot of the secrets you find in this game are actually useful in some way, so finding new gear is always very exciting.  You can take notes in the map if you need and, if you feel hardcore, you can draw the map yourself by choosing "old-school mode" at the start of the game.It's easy to learn its mechanics, but hard enough in general so it keeps you on your toes while you crawl in this maze full of monsters, traps, treasures and secrets. The scaling of difficulty is pretty well crafted, as is the level design and the enemy strength, and nothing is ever too hard for your party of four.What I did not like, though, is that the levels in the dungeons are quite weak in the variety department, so things could feel a bit repetitive after the first few levels. You kinda always see the same textures and scenarios over and over, albeit some exceptions in a couple of levels. Also, there are almost no bosses, or not many that you can call a boss, and I felt that it would've been a cool thing to add, so that's a bit disappointing. The final boss is also a bit underwhelming: without spoilers, I felt like it was really dumb. The ending too, it's not that great really.In summary, this is a rewarding and challenging experience, even if it is a bit repetitive. I still recommend it though, because there's not a lot of stuff like it.I can't wait to play the second one. I hear it is deeper, has more environments and it's more open than the first one. So that should be really fun to see.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Initially I voted Not Recommended for this game. Now that I've played Legend of Grimrock through, I decided to change my vote to Recommended with some qualification. There is a great deal to love about LoG. I only wish the developers had reconsidered a couple of design decisions. Understand that LoG is a dungeon-crawler not truly an RPG. There is no role-playing and very little story. The only RPG elements are that you can generate your own party and determine your characters stats as they level. You interact with no other characters and converse with no one, not even your own party members. Where LoG succeeds is in its retro style and feel, but with contemporary high-quality graphics. Additionally, LoG has plenty of difficult battles, many fun and intriguing puzzles, and considerable switch-hunting (be warned). LoG is not a turn-based game as you might expect for an RPG; it's real-time. Depending on your expectations and playing style, this feature can be annoying or thrilling, because monsters can attack you unexpectedly as you view your map, manage your inventory, or even as you level up. I loved this aspect of the game.Be aware, though, that if you have only average manual dexterity, the game can at times become very frustrating as you load, reload, ad nauseum, trying to "solve" running/timing puzzles that occur in the game. A couple of these puzzles can be bypassed, but then you will miss some of the game's most coveted items. A few are required to progress, however, and these can be game-stoppers. Worse, the movement system is not really geared to running/timing puzzles because you move one square at a time, and it's quite easy to overrun your mark--yet these puzzles require precise timing without any room for error. I found it irksome that I could understand a puzzle, but couldn't "solve" it because my fingers weren't fast enough. This dimension of the game made little sense to me; after all, the game purports to be a dungeon CRAWLER, and this genre traditionally relies on wit, thought, and tactics, not rapid finger movements like a platform game. I finally was able to deal with the two worst of these puzzles. For one of them, I found an AutoHotKey script that with minor adjustments did the work for me; for the second, inspired by the script just mentioned, I developed my own AutoHotKey script. That was more challenging and satisfying than endlessly retrying a puzzle my fingers just wouldn't do.In another odd design choice, the developers required some commonplace items to solve a puzzle essential to progress in the game, but then didn't include the items on that level. These were the kind of items players might have easily ditched as useless levels earlier. Being compelled to trudge back several levels to search for discarded items is not fun. Fortunately, you can use the LoG console to generate the items if you don't want to bother backtracking levels.Still, once you get beyond these issues, Legend of Grimrock is an enthralling game. If you're new to dungeon crawlers, don't expect something with the strong character interaction, huge world, and depth of story of, say, Dragon Age. That's not what Legend of Grimrock is about. But if the idea appeals to you of a dungeon-crawler/puzzler with heaps of combat, secrets, and wicked traps, go for it. You'll love Legend of Grimrock.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Initially I voted Not Recommended for this game. Now that I've played Legend of Grimrock through, I decided to change my vote to Recommended with some qualification. There is a great deal to love about LoG. I only wish the developers had reconsidered a couple of design decisions. Understand that LoG is a dungeon-crawler not truly an RPG. There is no role-playing and very little story. The only RPG elements are that you can generate your own party and determine your characters stats as they level. You interact with no other characters and converse with no one, not even your own party members. Where LoG succeeds is in its retro style and feel, but with contemporary high-quality graphics. Additionally, LoG has plenty of difficult battles, many fun and intriguing puzzles, and considerable switch-hunting (be warned). LoG is not a turn-based game as you might expect for an RPG; it's real-time. Depending on your expectations and playing style, this feature can be annoying or thrilling, because monsters can attack you unexpectedly as you view your map, manage your inventory, or even as you level up. I loved this aspect of the game.Be aware, though, that if you have only average manual dexterity, the game can at times become very frustrating as you load, reload, ad nauseum, trying to "solve" running/timing puzzles that occur in the game. A couple of these puzzles can be bypassed, but then you will miss some of the game's most coveted items. A few are required to progress, however, and these can be game-stoppers. Worse, the movement system is not really geared to running/timing puzzles because you move one square at a time, and it's quite easy to overrun your mark--yet these puzzles require precise timing without any room for error. I found it irksome that I could understand a puzzle, but couldn't "solve" it because my fingers weren't fast enough. This dimension of the game made little sense to me; after all, the game purports to be a dungeon CRAWLER, and this genre traditionally relies on wit, thought, and tactics, not rapid finger movements like a platform game. I finally was able to deal with the two worst of these puzzles. For one of them, I found an AutoHotKey script that with minor adjustments did the work for me; for the second, inspired by the script just mentioned, I developed my own AutoHotKey script. That was more challenging and satisfying than endlessly retrying a puzzle my fingers just wouldn't do.In another odd design choice, the developers required some commonplace items to solve a puzzle essential to progress in the game, but then didn't include the items on that level. These were the kind of items players might have easily ditched as useless levels earlier. Being compelled to trudge back several levels to search for discarded items is not fun. Fortunately, you can use the LoG console to generate the items if you don't want to bother backtracking levels.Still, once you get beyond these issues, Legend of Grimrock is an enthralling game. If you're new to dungeon crawlers, don't expect something with the strong character interaction, huge world, and depth of story of, say, Dragon Age. That's not what Legend of Grimrock is about. But if the idea appeals to you of a dungeon-crawler/puzzler with heaps of combat, secrets, and wicked traps, go for it. You'll love Legend of Grimrock.

Posted: April 29, 2015
												Legend of Grimrock is a first person, dungeon crawling, puzzle solving, RPG featuring 4 prisoners cast into the ancient dungeon of Grimrock in order to atone for their crimes.  This is a great game, a very simple but great game.  When I say simple, I mean it’s easy to pick up and start, but difficult to master.  You can be as good as you can be at an RPG, but you still eventually make a mistake in combat, and this game capitalizes and punishes mistakes with heavy damage and/or death.  However, this doesn't detract from the simple fun of this game. As I said in the beginning, you are controlling four prisoners (or less, you can go solo, but I seriously DONT recommend that) cast into the ancient dungeon/prison in the mountain of Grimrock, a mysterious and eerie mountain surrounded in death.  While it seems weird to control 4 people, while in first person, its actually not that bad, it’s actually quite interesting.The movement is tile based, as in each move, moves you a whole tile.  I personally like that change from the usual RPGs.The combat is cooldown and turn based, the front two party members can attack a target and must wait (based on the weapon and their DEX) to attack again.  There are 3 classes (as per usual) Fighter, Rogue, and Mage. Fighters are you usual warriors, utilizing swords, axes or maces and armor, I usually keep them in the front row as they are usually tougher.  Rogues use speed and timed strikes and ranged weapons, if you put skill points in Evasion you can eventually make it so all weapons they use are "reach" weapons, meaning a dagger can attack from the back row.  Mages are arcane users that utilize Air, Fire, Ice, and Earth magic, put enough points in one of those skills and the whole party learns to resist that type of damage.  Personally I found Fire and Earth to be the most dangerous early on, but that’s your choice.   I recommend balance, don't go using a whole team of Rogues for example, they are just too squishy.The game is also quite tough and unforgiving, as I said.  You can win battle after battle, but sooner or later you are going to get obliterated by some stupid mistake or a powerful enemy or a meanass trap, just be careful.The graphics are a bit dated, but I personally don't care that they are, I still loved the game.The puzzle solving mechanics are tricky, and definitely increase based on your game progress, heavy learning curve.  There are dozens of secret areas, hidden objects and treasures, and quite a few weapons.  Lots to find using the puzzle solving mechanics.An interesting feature, that I actually didn't do my first playthrough but will next time, is Old School Mode.   Put simply, no map at all.  You "must" use a pen and paper and manually put down the dungeons in order to remember them, or just google them, I think of that as cheating but near the end I did use google, so whatevs.The game also has a "food" mechanic, you aren't required to feed your party, but you get serious negs if you don't and they are starving.  Mainly, they don’t regenerate health or energy at all, unless you trek back to a Life Crystal (largeass blue crystals that fully restore and revive fallen party members must wait a bit after each use).  Obviously being in an abandoned prison/dungeon, food is a little scarce, but you'll usually find food when you need it.EXPLORE! If you are one of those people who burn through games as quickly as possible without exploring, DON'T! Go off the beaten the path often, that's where a majority of the treasure and loot and armor sets lie.My only kind of gripe is the a little overpowered enemies, a few of them.  Most of the enemies are fairly balanced and scale with you, but some are a little TOO good.  My biggest annoyance was the annoyingass giant crabs; yes GIANT crabs.  They have a ♥♥♥♥ ton of health and almost never miss and hit hard, TWICE! Just a little overpowered imo.  At higher levels, they hit pretty hard but so do you, but when you first run into them, they wipe the floor with your face, just be careful, they appear on the 4th level if my memory serves me right.A fun, exciting, tough and moddable game with a dungeon creator tossed into the game, decent graphics a little dated (granted this came out in 2010 but still), fun combat, lots of loot and monsters. The closed environment and a bit of lack of replay value and a few overpowered enemies are annoying.  However, I recommend everyone to play this game at least once. 9/10

Posted: January 11, 2014
												Pretty good dungeon crawler. I'm a big fan of the original Wizardry series (played 1, 2, 3, 7 and 8) and Eye of the Beholder (played 1 and 2). I miss those sorts of games, and Grimrock made me feel nostalgic, so I think it's a success.However, there were a couple things I didn't like very much. For me, much of the fun in RPGs and dungeon crawlers is the random loot, which comes in large part from random monsters. Every monster and item in Grimrock appears to be pre-placed. I think they did a fine job doing this, but any interest I may have had in replaying it with a different party has been eliminated by knowing that everything else about a second playthrough would be exactly the same. Maybe you'd like to have two characters wielding crossbows? Well, it seems you're out of luck. There appears to be only one crossbow in the game. You can't find another. There are also only a handful of quarrels -- about 20 I think. There are no vendors, so you can't buy/trade for more crossbows or quarrels. (Quarrels are reusable - you can pick them up again after the monster dies.)The other thing I like about party-based RPGs is exploring strategy. Particular combinations of buffs, debuffs, and attacks make combat richer and deeper, and reward you for taking time to think through your choices. Grimrock's combat, however, is mostly about dodging. There are very few buffs/debuffs, and it mostly doesn't make all that much difference what order your characters attack in. Which monster you attack first can make a difference, but mostly you won't be presented with much in the way of choice about that.In Wizardry 8, I started a brand-new game to explore a particular strategy. Rangers could get cricitical hits with ranged weapons, and gadgeteers could eventually learn to combine certain crossbows together so they could shoot three times per attack. Three rangers and a gadgeteer were hard in the early stages, and levelling up my gadgeteer and finding enough crossbows to equip each of my rangers with a triple-shot was a fun challenge. But once accomplished, my rangers were a rapid-fire killing posse, firing as many as 45 quarrels per combat round between them.  Buff them with speed, debuff the monsters with slowness and extra vulnerability to crits, and we weren't afraid of anything, especially if we could see it coming a long way off. The problem ended up being that it was awfully hard to carry around enough quarrels to get through more than a handful of fights. I had to take on some NPCs just to act as mules, and every trip to town involved clearing out every single vendor's stock of quarrels.We won't have any experiences like that in Grimrock, and that was disappointing to me.

Posted: December 15, 2013
												One of the best classic-like RPGs out there. Has a pen-and-paper feel to it and very unique combat.This is a tile-based game wherein you control 4 characters (a mixture of fighter / rogue / mage). You can either use pre-determined characters or create your own which involves distributing stat points and choosing various attributes. You can make everything from a tank, to a melee rogue, archer, spell-caster, etc.Movement is limited to moving forward / back / left / right along the tiles. This actually works out pretty well, partly because the setting is that of a jail or dungeon so it feels very confined to begin with.Combat is very unique and pretty addictive. Your characters are arranged in a square - two in the front, two in the back. You really need to plan your fights and reposition your characters as you go. For example, a melee character may not be able to attack from the back row, but he won't take any damage either. Archers and spell-casters do well in the back, but take a lot of damage in the front. Etc. You attack by clicking your characters' weapons, each of which is on a cool-down, which gives you time to re-position your characters in real-time. I also find myself strafing back-and-forth (recall the way movement works, so you can try to force enemies between a few tiles). In larger fights, this can work against you as you can get trapped in a corner. There's a lot of strategy going on.Spell casting is also very unique. You click a combination of runes to cast a spell. This requires a bit of thought as you can't save rune combinations.

Posted: May 25, 2013
												Legend of Grimrock is an old-school RPG that harkens back to old first-person dungeon crawlers such as the venerable Eye of the Beholder series, the older Might and Magics or the Wizardry series.My first playthrough on normal difficulty took close to 20 hours and this was considering that i had skipped a couple of puzzles and also had to consult the net for solutions to some of them.Puzzles are the core of the game. Some of them are essential for game progression, most are optional, and ALL of them are very cleverly crafted and are absolutely fun and challenging. You will definitely get a sense of satisfaction if you manage to solve it without any help.However because of this, I personally felt that the game focused too much on puzzle solving, and the game sometimes felt more like a puzzle game with RPG elements instead of an RPG with puzzles.Instead of having puzzles subtly presented like in the old Eye of the Beholder series, Grimrock literally hands you a puzzle room and even puts out a label of the puzzle's name.On the whole, this makes the whole game feel more like 13 levels of puzzle rooms where you just need to solve it to progress instead of an RPG with a coherent story that gives context to the puzzles.Story is definitely not Grimrock's strong point, and it only provides an introductory excuse to let the player know why he is in a dungeon. As a game touted as an RPG, the treasure and loot selection are unfortunately not exciting. There are only a couple of limited choices. This game also features the most rediculous looking final boss in an RPG ever.Music is very well done and sounds appropriately cinematic and epic. However, there are only 2 tracks in the whole game. The art style while looking very modern, recycles alot of textures and makes every dungeon level feel the same as the earlier ones.The main gripe I had was the magic system, which was overly complicated and too frustrating to use. It actually requires you to remember spell combinations and click on them fast during battle. I felt that they should have had a simpler approach to this, or at least provide a simpler alternative style. (Eg: why can't we right click on the mage's hand, choose the spell i want and just cast it?)Despite its flaws, Legend of Grimrock is still a very good game and is a worthy addition to the past glorious dungeon-crawlers. The fact that the entire game was made by only a 4 man team with a limited budget really blows the mind. Whats more, they even allowed player modding on this game which is probably a first time for games of this type and genre.For veterans of old-school RPG dungeon-crawlers, this game is a definite must buy. For newer gamers who have never experienced such old-school gameplay before however, it is better to review the gameplay videos before deciding if this game is for you. The play style in this game may not appeal to modern gamers.Overall Rating: 8.0 / 10An excellent and authentic old-school dungeon crawler that veterans would enjoy. I cannot wait to see a sequel to this game. Two thumbs up. Don't miss it.

Posted: October 10, 2014
												Legend of Grimrock employs a great deal of forward thinking to what seems to be a long-forgotten genre of RPGs.  The first-person tile-based dungeon crawl has recently been dominated by Japanese developers, mostly ATLUS, and while great games in their own right, they lack the feeling that the early Wizardy and Might & Magic games had.  Every single bit of Grimrock feels deliberate; crisp visuals give way to crisp sound, providing a surprising depth of ambiance and atmosphere.  Indeed, each room and item has a purpose for it's placement, adding to the immersion.Grimrock's combat moves to a beat - each monster moves at a certain pace, and moving with it is the key to surviving.  The brings a certain amount of tension to each fight, and moving around the environment has its own unique challenges.  Twitchy fingers are practically a requirement on Hard but this is common in dungeon crawls, and after a small amount of time movements between attacks become second-nature.  Magic in Grimrock is fairly straightforward - a board of 9 runes comprise each spell in the game, and combinations are explained in scrolls found throughout the dungeon.  This is probably the biggest misstep Grimrock makes.  It's very easy to progress down a skilltree in a specific element of magic, only to find one or two scrolls relating to the element.  It's a frustrating feeling, and makes the player feel like knowledge of the exact location of each spell is required.  As good as the combat is, the heart of Grimrock is exploration and puzzle solving, something that is (thankfully) executed flawlessly.  Constant observation of your environment is a must especially in the later levels where it's required for progression.  It's tough to explain the puzzle system without giving too much away - but each level of the prison brings new challenges and secrets.Legend of Grimrock is the breath of life into a genre nowadays only found on handhelds, and aside from a few hiccups,  presents a polished experience that indie RPGs should aspire.

												Holy Nut Balls! This game is virtual crack. Take the old fashioned dungeon RPG from the nostalgic begginings of PC gaming and give it a modern twist. Once you create your awesome characters you start off in the dungeon and fight off some big♥♥♥♥♥snails and solve some puzzles that become more complicated in the later levels. Unlike the old memorable dungeon RPGs, Grimrock's combat is not turnbased and  if you get hit, its mostly your fault. The magic system is a bit difficult to use, but its actually very unique. 												Legend of Grimrock is modernised version of many of the classic dungeon crawling experiences of the 1990s, taking inspiration from such games as Ultima Underworld, Dungeon Master, and Dungeons & Dragons, this games makes for a deep grid based action role-playing game.Starting off with next to nothing you and your ragtag bunch of prisoners must battle through levels and levels of dungeons clearing them, finding secrets and reaching the levels. Appoint XP points into each of your characters to unlock new abilities such as spells and the ability to use different weapons. Change your party line; do you prefer to use your mage on the front line? Move him to the front two and watch him destroy the enemy. Or, do you prefer to bash in creatures? Put up your shields and use your heavy hitters to deal the maximum amount of damage. Posted: December 5, 2013
												Legend of Grimrock is what I'd consider a minimalist RPG. What I mean by this, is the story and premise is set up right at the begining of your play, then after that you're left to your own devices. You basically form your own story while you explore the dungeons. It's very much in the ideals of the original Ultima series, where it's all about exploration, finding secrets, and killing monsters. You get to either spawn four prisoners that you'll take on your journey, or customize them to exactly who you want with you. The races and the types are familiar (warrior, wizard, rogue), but the way you can build them is where the difference comes in. The game play itself is also aikin back to what RPGs used to be on the computer. Everything works in blocks, you can turn, sidestep, and all of that good stuff during battle, but it all works on a grid. Along with this you can either choose to draw your own map, or play with one that populates as you go depending on how old school you want to be. The graphics bring you into the game and the monsters are well designed and fun to fight. There's a lot of secrets worth looking for meaning you're going to be checking every wall for loose rocks, or for some of the other ways you open the doors. On top of this, the replayability is excellent because of the mod community. Currently there's a mod that keeps most of the original set up but makes things harder and adds more dungeons, or you can just download the added dungeons that other people have created.Over all this is a great game that, for how it's designed, there isn't much to complain about and I recommend this to anyone that's an RPG fan, especially if you remember the originals like Ultima and Final Fantasy for NES.

												I apologize in advance for my star-eyed enthusiasm.It's challenging. It's charming. It's old school. Grimrock, to me, is a game of imagination. While obviously nowhere near to the extent of pen & paper, your characters (the most important aspect) are left up to you to flesh out. This is where all the fun begins. The character system is pretty flexible for its simplicity, and simplicity makes for great gameplay balance. The aformentioned flexibility also adds to replay value with there being many combinations of builds, although your mileage may vary. The classes are well balanced, all except the mage. They are an insult to the name "magic-user" because they aren't nearly versatile enough to make up for their many weaknesses.(I personally solved my inept mage problem with Cheat Engine by giving him 8 skill points per level) - use "double" as the address type.The gameplay itself is a delicate mix of puzzle-solving, action, character management and hoarding with a bit of story advancement thrown in. Combat is real-time and fairly simple, but has several strategic and tactical elements, such as party order, flanking, backstabbing, and rudimentry dodging. Items are particularly well done. Everything you might expect in an RPG is there and balanced well, including the modest amount of interesting, unique, and powerful items.While Grimrock does have a few rough edges, it is nonetheless expertly crafted.

												Old-school design, new-school look.  Legend of Grimrock is a nod to dungeon crawlers of the past with its first-person view and grid terrain dungeons (think first-person rogue-like as an analogy).  You create a party of four (races: human, minotaur, lizzardman, and insectoid; classes: warrior, rogue, and mage) and set out on your quest to traverse down the pits of Grimrock--the highest summit in a fantasy world. I am so addicted to this editor and pretty good at it too if I might say!Seriously, I cannot break away from the level editor long enough to write a review about the game which is also really awesome! There are scripting abilities using the included Lua scripting language, but know that you "do not" need to use scripts at all to create full blown adventures with stories included, if you want to write them on walls! :-)  I used Lua to write messages on screen, instead of walls.  Say, sometimes you want to set the mood with some text as you enter a room…  You can easily place an invisible switch on the floor and link it to some scripted text.  I only needed scripting so my text would show up on the HUD.  If you want text on walls, it is much easier!  You basically set a text box on a wall and type what you want it to say.  It shows up on the wall as a golden unfamiliar text.  Kind of like the old "Lord British's Ultima textstyle".  Then you click on it to read it.You can easily insert short or long text onto walls to create a story if you want, or to leave cryptic messages for puzzles you can create. 												A beautiful love-letter to the Dungeon Crawlers of the 1970's and 80's.Smart. Beautiful.Tough, but fair.The game is PACKED with secrets, secrets, secrets and you are constantly keeping an eye on your food meter since resting while starving does you no good. The game is well-balanced but does NOT hold your hand-- this is not for your little sister to play, even on normal difficulty.Walking on a grid system took some getting used to, but the game is well-paced enough that by the time it hits its stride you're a master at it. The game is going to give your the best experience during the FIRST playthrough only, though. As it is a puzzle game at heart-- the puzzles don't change. Going back through a second or third time would only be for the over-achievers that want to find all the secrets, hidden items, skulls (yes skulls), treasures and so on. I got 22/40 achievements just playing it through the first time. I only had to look up the solution to two puzzles in the entire 20hrs of gameplay, and felt halway clever the rest of the time. The game does a good job of coyly telling you what to look for, then letting you walk RIGHT past it soon after and NOT getting that cool sword that's hidden in the walls.Be patient, Be smart, Be methodical. Grimrock IS out to get you. Food is scarce and some enemies are a bit overpowered--- again, tough but fair. You'll have a blast wandering down its tunnels. I wholly recommend it. 9/10

												Buy this.If you like any games that are non-action oriented (adventure, point-and-click, story games, RPGs, strategy games, etc.) this game will probably fit into a category you can enjoy.The game assumes you are intelligent and you play through the game with this in mind. You pass up dozens and dozens of secrets, unbeknownst to you until you finish the game and realize you didn't even get half of them. Each secret you discover, puzzle you finish, feels like it is "yours" because it takes significant effort to accomplish.It would be simple to download this game, open up a walkthrough, and breeze through it. Don't. Play it and stress over every detail, search every nook and cranny, draw your own maps and write down your own notes on a notepad in front of you. Treat the game seriously and as a test of your intellect. Posted: April 21, 2012
												Legend of Grimrock is my favorite indie release this year. Many compare it to Dungeon Master, but I find it equally reminiscent of old pen and paper RPGs, requiring equal parts wit and might to survive. As you traverse the dungeon, you’ll encounter floors with deadly traps, vicious enemies, numerous puzzles and secrets. The puzzles are satisfying and require truly clever solutions in many cases. Similarly, combat requires guile and agility, and you must constantly be on the move, exploit enemies’ weaknesses where ever possible and avoid being cornered at all costs. One of the game’s few negative aspects is the absolute lack of any instruction (even the tutorial fails to explain game mechanics in any detail) and would perhaps benefit from a “show, don’t tell” approach. All in all, Grimrock provides a great amount of content at a price that’s quite reasonable. I’ve already logged about 50 hours and still haven’t uncovered all the secrets.

Posted: March 13, 2016
												Well, as you can see from the playtime I've put a lot of hours into this game.  I was a huge huge fan of Dungeon Master, then Chaos Strikes Back, and of course the Eye of the Beholder series.  I even tried my hardest to like StoneKeep, but it was just a touch too formulaic to be considered an 'evolution'.. It was really just a repetition.   At the time, the Bards Tale games were also exploring the rectilinear 2.5D game approach, and I did quite like them, but they were vastly inferior at projecting an atmosphere (I felt).    So, I hope you get an idea of where my review is coming from: I'm a die-hard Dungeon Master fan, who really likes the genre, but is looking for DM with improvemetns.Legend of Grimrock is a superb game, there is no doubt about it.  "Polised" doesn't even come close to explaining just how wonderful the world is.  The rocks glisten, the toches flicker, and everything has the exact same 'feel' as Dungeon master, from the pressure-plates, and doors opening to the 'worms' (now snails) which offer up repulsive-sounding chunks of meat to keep your party alive.   The big question that you want to ask is "Does it represent 25 years of advancement over Dungeon Master?".  The answer is "mostly".  I'll explain in a bit more detail...The game is effectively the same as Dungeon Master: You start out at the 'top' of a dungeon. In DM, you were a party of resurrected adventurers controlled by a wizard (who you could see if you battled your way all the way back up the dungeon and used the 'see through walls' spell on the first door!).  In LoG, you're a party of four adventurers, imprisoned for unknown reasons in a big mountain.   The door closes, and this is where the first main difference arises: Choosing your party.In DM, you 'floated about' as a spirit essence, looking at paintings of dead adventurers, choosing who to resurrect, and who to 'take' but remould into your desires.  This was completely revolutionary.  LoG picks a very AD&D approach instead, and just allows you to stat-roll and custom-build your party.   DM allowed you a lot of freedom over your party. It was pretty much possible to get anywhere and do anything with any party (although a lone adventurer was too hard for me to ever complete the game with).  LoG is essentially the same, however there are some classes which are completely useless, and some races which appear to be awesome (minotaur).  I took a Rogue, but didn't look at the achievements list, so never got assassination, and therefore never got the one thing that the rogue is good for, the backstab Steam Achievement. Pah.OKay, so you pick your formulaic team (Fighters up front, mage(s) and rogue(s) up the back), and head into the dungeon.   The first level is a training level, as you'd expect. You're deposited naked, so you find some loincloths, daggers and rocks, and use them to bludgeon the locals, as you'd expect...  There are a few traps, and puzzles, but by and large, it's your standard training level.  HOWEVER, the game's true nature comes to the fore at this point...The training level can kill you.  And is does. Over and over.  You see, there's a trick to playing LoG, which you have to learn RIGHT at the beginning, or you're going to die. and die. and die.  You must never try to go toe-to-toe with an enemy. You will die.   The monsters are always scaled to be a difficult challenge.  To fight you must find at LEAST a 2x2 grid, and strafe, rotate, hit, strafe, rotate, hit, strafe, rotate, hit... and so on.. and so on.. until one of you is dead.    Woe betide you if there are two enemies: This is a retilinear circus of death.. you'll get trapped, and die.  For two enemies, you need a 3x3 grid, making sure never to step into a corner cell if you can help it!  And so, you quickly learn the mathematics of LoG.  Quick count: 3 enemies, right I'll need a 4x4 space to dodge around them in, at least.If you're REALLY lucky, you'll come across them in a snake-like corridor, and can use their abysmal path finding against them.  Monsters will often sidestep with you, so you can pop-left, shoot, pop-right, and the monster will take the arrow or fireball in the face, then step right again, and now there's some rock between you.. You wait to cooldown, and rinse repeat.I'll say this again: Never ever ever try to go toe-to-toe with an enemy.  Sometimes you can't help it. In this case, you're probably boned, but try and slash your way out of it as best you can:  There are some 'secrets' which FORCE you to be in the middle of a swarm of things (Fighter's Challenge), and in this case, you're boned.  Over and over.. until you get lucky and reload enough times that a space randomly appears in front of you, or whatever, and you're able to retreat out of the swarm... Something like that..Supplies are in short supply:  Lack of food is the main impetus to keep moving.  There were many times that my party were getting low, because I'd been searching for secrets, and I just had to plough on into the next level, to get some food.    At first I found it annoying: Cosntantly running low: There are penalties for being hungry!  But then I realised it was to stop people stagnating on earlier levels.   I remember in DM having my entire party encumbered with Worm Rounds because we'd camped near a spawn point, and I ended up dagging them up and down, and up and down, three or four levels down from the spawn point, so I could have a stash.   Similar things happen in LoG. There's a famous 'snail room', but you only get two snails, which is barely enough to keep two party members alive.  However, they do replenish every time you step a certain distance from the room...As you get deeper and deeper, the enemies stay just as hard.  Okay, I KNOW they're getting harder, but I'm getting better at the same pace.  So, while a snail on level one needs ten dagger-hits, a cthulu-faced magic-wielding lightning-thrower-evil-demon on Level 12 still takes ten lightning-sword hits.   So, the 'experience' changes a little with the variety of ranged vs. melee monsters, but the game stays uniformly difficult.  In DM, there definitely felt to be an advancement in ability, and monsters became easier.. So in DM, that demon would take three lightning-sword hits, if you see what I mean?Descending through LoG, the 'tunnels' feel slightly different. You start off in fairly rustic 'sewers'?, and then descent into perfectly rectilinear dressed-stone corridors.  They stay this way until the very last level, which goes very industrial, and it becomes clear what the game's emblem is all about.There's a LOT of side-activity here.  You can plough through without finding many secrets, but the majority of the good stuff is behind tiny buttons, and so on, so it really pays to explore.   However, there's always that looming hunger, so you can't spend too long.  There's about enough surplus food int he dungeon (without snail-mining), to get you back to Level 1 from Level 12 two or three times, if you forgot something, before you really start to run dangerously low.I'd say my main gripe about this game is the w ay that the skill 'trees' (or just skill List) works.  In DM, you started off beign able to do "14", (fire), and then learned "144" (fireball)... But once you leveled up, you could try for "244", bigger fireball... sometimes it'd work, sometimes it wouldn't.   LoG has nothing like this.     My second main gripe is that magic needs SO MANY DAMNED CLICKS to work.   five perfectly-placed clicks on smal squares, while you're trying to strafe,turn,hit,strafe.... is a REAL pain the a$$!!!!   All in all, I'd say this was a really excellent attempt to remake Dungeon Master.   They've missed some of the fun in a few areas, and instead concentrated on graphical beauty.  Doesn't stop me from recommending this though. It's a great game, so long as you learn the one cardinal rule: Do not go toe-to-toe with an enemy if you can help it!
